summary: Email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorney and attorney Sigrid McCawley coordinating interviews with victims/witnesses for the Epstein investigation in October 2019. The emails discuss scheduling, travel logistics, and potential video conferences for multiple individuals.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.role: Partner at Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, attorney representing victims
persons.context: Attorney coordinating interviews for her clients (victims/witnesses) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. She is arranging travel, scheduling, and communication between her clients and prosecutors.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Prosecutor from the Southern District of New York coordinating and scheduling interviews with victims/witnesses represented by Sigrid McCawley as part of the Epstein investigation.

connections.description: Attorney and prosecutor coordinating interview schedules for victims/witnesses in the Epstein investigation.
McCawley represents multiple victims/witnesses and is arranging their interviews with prosecutors, including handling travel and logistical issues.
Prosecutor seeking to interview victims/witnesses as part of the ongoing Epstein investigation.

events.title: Scheduled victim interview
events.description: Planned interview between prosecutors and a victim/witness at the U.S. Attorney's office, initially scheduled for 2pm.

events.title: Victims' meeting and potential interviews
events.description: A victims' meeting scheduled, with potential follow-up interviews with prosecutors afterward.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Prosecutors from the SDNY were actively interviewing victims/witnesses in the Epstein case in October 2019, months after Epstein's death.
Attorney Sigrid McCawley represented multiple victims/witnesses and was coordinating their travel and interviews with federal prosecutors.
At least one victim/witness had travel difficulties requiring coordination with a victims' coordinator, suggesting potential logistical or legal hurdles.
Prosecutors were flexible in scheduling, including considering video conferences (Skype) for witnesses who could not travel.
The emails reference a victim who "was brought to the US by Epstein a number of times," indicating international travel patterns relevant to the investigation.
